Solemnly descending in rectitude.
The mortal realm illumined,
Protecting the state and quelling disorder.
The peerless Sage manifests,
Responding to devotion,
Bestowing grace and saving the people.
In perfect clarity, all prayers are answered,
Every wish fulfilled,
All petitions confirmed in sincerity.
Not only kings, ministers, Daoists, monks, scholars, and commoners—
All sentient beings who reverently tend the incense fire
Shall see their intentions realized.
Thus, by this merit, goodness abides in the world,
Devoted to aiding others.
Those who receive this grace shall prosper beyond measure.
Now, having received the Sage’s protection,
For nation and family alike,
How could we dare forget the Great Dao?
Prolonging blessings and increasing years,
We forever pray for the safeguarding of the throne.

Having already bestowed grace upon the realm, one hundred and four memorials of *Awakening the Sage* were presented, all of which have fulfilled their transformative purpose. Respectfully, within the Jade Ford Garden, a sacred hall was established to repay the celestial oversight. Having received the manifestation of divine presence, the Perfected Warrior was further granted the status of a guardian deity of the state and household. In reverence for the Supreme Sage, the Perfected Warrior, it is fitting to confer the title: *Grand Marshal of the Three Primordials of Highest Clarity, Commander of the Nine Heavens’ Patrol, Great General of the Left Celestial Array of the Northern Culmen’s Right Wall, True Lord of the Dark Heaven’s Numinous Response, Venerable of the Primordial Transformation, Serene Illumination, Perfect Clarity, Majestic Treasure, Pure and Equal to Heaven, Protector of the State and Pacifier of the People, Longevity-Responding Blessing Deity, Wise and Virtuous, Filial and Sagely, Civil and Martial, Queller of Disorder, Sagely and Merciful Heavenly Marquis*.

By imperial decree, the turtle and serpent are to be enfeoffed and the rites carried out accordingly. The streets of the Two Sages, the Turtle and Serpent, are recorded in the opening lines of this scripture, beneath the passage on the pine demon’s subdued poison.

Thus, one must meditate in stillness with utmost sincerity and recite the divine incantation. "Thus" (*ran*) refers to the Dao’s guidance. "Still meditation" means sitting in a tranquil chamber. "Utmost" (*qian*) denotes profound sincerity. "Faithful recitation" means to intone with devotion.

This deity is numinous and luminous. Striking the teeth and reciting the incantation—incantation being the means by which sound is emitted to repel evil.

The *Scripture of the Void Sovereign* states: "When the body’s filth is unclean, it is washed with worldly water. When the heart’s filth is unclean, it is washed with the Dharma’s words, or by confessing one’s sins, which is also a form of self-purification."

In the northern Dark Heavens, the profound and boundless Divine Lord, the True and Numinous of the Dark Warrior, undergoes myriad transformations. Ascending the heavens and overturning the earth, he drives thunder and races through clouds, his retinue of a thousand myriad banners sweeping away demonic miasmas. Thunder Lords attend him as retainers, Jade Maidens serve as generals. Ghosts and spirits submit, dragons and tigers flee in concealment. His might stabilizes the Five Peaks, and the ten thousand spirits obey. With clanging bells and resounding drums, he traverses the cosmos, capturing rebellious ghosts, crushing and severing demonic grasses. Expelling evil and aiding the upright, the Dao’s qi ever arrives.

*Hasten, hasten, in accordance with the statutes and ordinances of the Primordial Celestial Sovereign!*

According to the *Scripture of Purple Radiance*: This divine incantation originates from the secret writings of the Divine Treasure Lord. Born of the Great Yin, essence of the Water trigram, it corresponds above to the Void and Danger constellations, its form uniting turtle and serpent. Roaming the ninefold earth, it governs and commands the myriad spirits. No darkness escapes its scrutiny, no desire remains unfulfilled. At the end and beginning of kalpas, it severs and subdues demonic essences, rescuing and protecting all beings, bringing peace to households and nations alike.

When the cyclical number reaches the final *jia*, demonic qi spreads. The Celestial Sovereign issues his decree, and thus I descend in numinous manifestation. Concealing and revealing the true teaching, sweeping away evil and averting warfare, transforming and harmonizing the multitudes, aiding the resurgence of the central reign.

Should any petty ghost dare appear, my single gaze will topple the Five Peaks.

*Hasten, hasten, in accordance with the statutes and ordinances of the Great Mystery!*

As recorded in the ninth section of the ninth rank of the *Three Caverns Great Rites* in the *Chapter on Practicing the Dao*: "Divine incantations, most excellent of all, drive away epidemics, sweep away demonic miasmas, and repel malevolent spirits."

Thus concludes the third scroll of the *Wondrous Scripture of the Divine Incantation of the Great Sage of the Dark Heavens, the Perfected Warrior, as Spoken by the Most High*.

Here begins the fourth scroll of the *Wondrous Scripture of the Divine Incantation of the Great Sage of the Dark Heavens, the Perfected Warrior, as Spoken by the Most High*.

Here begins the *Inner Teachings of Ascending the Dao: A Record Compiled by Chen Yin with Annotations*, as transmitted by the Wondrous Practitioner of the True Way:

The Wondrous Practitioner of the True Way declared: "The marvel of virtue and power, the cause of manifest responses—I have been fortunate to hear of these in secret, and in an instant, my delusion was dispelled. Though my ears have heard, there remain those of barbarian tribes and foolish, dull-witted folk who, though their ears may hear of virtue, hold no faith in their hearts. If there are indeed karmic retributions, let a single word be shown to them."

The Perfected One, having already attained and inquired into the cultivation of the Dark Warrior’s bodily practices, whose virtue and conduct are luminously wondrous, whose numinous responses and transformations follow causes to their fruition—all beings, all people, take refuge in him.

Yet again, he posed a question: "As for the foolish and dull-witted, the coarse and ignorant, the barbarian tribes, the stubborn and unenlightened—who among them reveres Heaven and Earth? Who believes in the divine Perfected? Yet each shall receive retribution according to their due. What, then, shall be the fate of those who do not believe in the August Dark Warrior?"

The Supreme Emperor of the Purple Tenuity replied:
"Though they be foolish and dull-witted, they must know heat and cold. Though they dwell among barbarians, they must understand suffering and joy."

The Great Emperor swiftly resolved the Wondrous Practitioner’s doubt, saying: "Heat and cold, suffering and joy—who does not know these?"

Thus, in an age of adversity, the Most High first dispatched Lord Lao of the Hu, together with the stellar lodges Horn, Neck, Root, Chamber, Heart, Tail, and Winnowing Basket, to transform the Nine Yi tribes of the East. Lord Lao of the Qiang, together with Dipper, Ox, Girl, Void, Danger, House, and Wall, to transform the Five Di tribes of the North. Lord Lao of the Di, together with Straddler, Bond, Stomach, Pleiades, Net, Turtle Beak, and Orion, to transform the Six Rong tribes of the West. Lord Lao of the Yue, together with Well, Ghost, Willow, Star, Spread, and Wing, to transform the Eight Man tribes of the South. Lord Lao of the Cang, together with [the remaining lodges], to transform the Central Plains of the Middle Kingdom.

As the *Record of Rites* states: "The peoples of the five directions, though their speech and silence differ, their desires and tastes diverge, each has their settled dwelling, harmonious flavors, suitable garments, and useful implements." Since they are the most spirited among all beings, how could they fail to know suffering and joy, heat and cold? Those who reach this realm must earnestly give thanks to the Supreme Perfected. Those who receive grace—how could they forget to offer sacrifices?

To believe is to have a spirit and soul that are pure and bright. To believe is to sincerely practice the laws of the Five Constants. Naturally, the spirit’s heart becomes pure, and the soul’s intent becomes clear and luminous.

The Primordial Lady declared: "A person who performs a single good deed finds their heart settled and their body at peace."

The Heavenly Worthy of the Primordial Void proclaimed: "A person who performs a single good deed brings peace to a hundred spirits." How much more so for one who accumulates thousands or tens of thousands of good deeds—they shall surely ascend to the Great Dao!

To transgress, however, is to invite calamity and misfortune in abundance. To transgress is to act against righteousness, to move contrary to principle. When evil ripens to its appointed time, calamities and misfortunes coil and entwine, repeatedly striking like a relentless storm.

The Great Emperor, in his boundless compassion, briefly admonishes through these eight retributions. In the world, those who diligently honor the Dark Emperor with incense and offerings find their misfortunes scattering like lightning, while blessings arise like clouds. Thus, even the poor and childless among descendants may attain the five human felicities: first, longevity; second, wealth. To dwell in wealth is felicity indeed. Yet those without descendants incur, as Mencius deemed, the fault of unfiliality. In ancient times, the man of Hua offered a blessing, saying: "May Emperor Yao enjoy long life, wealth, and many sons." Yao declined the blessing, for to raise unworthy sons is as good as having none—his position was no different from Shun’s son-in-law. His son, too, acted likewise, abdicating the throne to Minister Yu. Yangzi said: "The young of the mud-dauber dies and meets the potter wasp, who prays, 'Be like me, be like me!' Over time, it comes to resemble it." How swiftly did the seventy disciples come to resemble Confucius! Moreover, comparing the affairs of Yao and Shun suffices to show that the matters of descendants are subject to the Mandate of the Supreme Emperor.

The Primordial Lady declared: "A person who accumulates fifty good deeds in past lives shall see their descendants flourish in this world. One who establishes nine hundred good deeds shall give rise to sages and worthies in their lineage." The *Scripture of Responding to the Times* states: "When the Great Dao was first divided, in the West arose the Buddha, named *Namo* the Realm of Constantly Observing Self-Existence. He established the Universal Gate Vow, responding to the prayers of all. Should people of later generations make offerings and pay homage, seeking sons, sons shall be born; seeking daughters, daughters shall be born." How much more so for the Dark Emperor and the Three Mao Perfected Lords, who likewise fulfill the wishes of the people? Have they not heard of the affairs of Wang Zhi and Zhu Mu?

According to the *Records of the Awakening of the Sage*: During the Huangyou era, Wang Zhi, the Prefectural Inspector of Jizhou and Palace Attendant, had a wife, Lady Jiao of Shouchang Commandery. One day, she saw a withered branch of a pomegranate tree in the rear garden suddenly emit smoke. She poured water upon it, and a halo formed, revealing the True Warrior. Lady Jiao bowed and knocked her head in reverence. Though but a humble mortal, she was fortunate to encounter the descent of a Supreme Perfected One, who came to deliver her child. She had heard that to remain childless all her life was a grave karmic misfortune. The True Warrior promptly descended with a merciful decree, saying: "Your sincerity has moved me to fulfill your wish. Await the third day of the third month next year at Zhen Guan Temple, where I shall grant you a son." Lady Jiao bowed in gratitude, and the sacred trace vanished. She returned and informed her husband. When the appointed day arrived, the couple went together to the temple. Amidst the throng, they burned incense when suddenly a boy of six or seven, claiming to have no parents, seized Wang Zhi and Lady Jiao by the hands. Wang took him home to raise, and the child was naturally bright and clever. Later, he presented himself before the emperor to petition for grace. Emperor Renzong summoned him and, learning that Wang had no heir, Wang recounted the entire affair. The emperor bestowed upon the boy the name Wang Yuan and betrothed him to the Princess of Yue. Wang Yuan passed the military examinations, was enfeoffed as a Duke Consort, and granted a mansion.

Again, in the *Records of the Awakening of the Sage*: Zhu Mu of Leping County in Raozhou served with impartiality in office and conducted himself with humility in his village. Throughout his life, he reverently maintained the incense and offerings to the True Warrior. Yet he lamented his lack of a son. On the seventh night of the seventh month, his wife said: "I just dreamed of a Daoist who drew a plate from his sleeve, bearing a single jujube. He fed it to me, saying, 'This is a divine jujube bestowed by Heaven.' He bade me swallow it, and its fragrance permeated my body." Zhu Mu smelled an extraordinary fragrance filling the room. The following year, she gave birth to a son, whom they named Tianxi. At five, he was already memorizing texts with intelligence; by seven, his name resounded throughout the land. Emperor Shenzong summoned him to court, where he was tested on the classics, histories, and the works of the Hundred Schools, reciting without error. He also responded swiftly to the emperor’s poetic prompts. Pleased, the emperor bestowed upon him the title Gentleman for Fulfilling Service and granted him gold and silk for purchasing books. The Three Departments examined Zhu Mu’s divine prodigy and declared him an auspicious omen for the state.

The Han Chancellor Chen Ping once said: "I have employed many secret strategies, which the Daoists forbid. My lineage shall surely decline." He knew that his attainment of wealth and nobility would leave him without descendants. According to the *Chapter on Protecting Descendants*: "For those whose lineage is in decline, one should redeem their fate by releasing living beings to resolve it." Yet the poor often have many children. Yuan Xian said: "I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty." Confucius said: "To be poor yet without resentment—such were Yan and Zeng." Yet Yan Hui, second only to the sages in wisdom, and Zeng Shen, a great worthy, still suffered the retribution of bodily poverty. How much more so for those who flatter and deceive! To be poor yet have many children is a karmic transgression from past lives.

The *Celestial Scripture of Penetrating Chapters* states: "Those born into hardship, with no one to rely upon, who encounter enemies and suffer the company of many relatives, living in daily anxiety and shared poverty, enduring cold and hunger—such trials are difficult to resolve at once. Yet if one quiets evil thoughts and does not harbor resentment, this is called inner harmony, and one may swiftly escape the encircling nets of retribution. But if envy and malice persist, one shall fall into evil destinies."

The *Record of Zhao Qi’s Dream* recounts: One night, he dreamed that the former husband of his late wife, the Gentleman of the Palace and Outer Bureau Li Shu, came to his home and bowed, seeking an audience. He said: "The netherworld has now fixed the day of my sentencing. I am to be reborn as a girl in the poor household of the Liu family in the Seventh Emperor’s Ward. I have heard that this family, burdened by poverty and many children, intends to kill her. I shall scarcely regain a human form." He repeated this thrice, saying, "How grievous!"

Having expressed his gratitude, he wiped his tears and departed weeping. Zhao Qi awoke and recounted the dream to his wife, Lady Fan, who confirmed she had dreamed the same. At dawn, he hastened to the Liu household and found they had indeed given birth to a girl, whom they were about to drown in the water—her life hanging by a thread. Zhao Qi bestowed gold upon them, rescuing Li Shu from the brink of drowning.

Generally, poverty and wealth alternate like shadows, and the transformations of Heaven’s principle defy prediction. Observe but a single village: within a decade, fortunes reverse, families wax and wane, and who can claim constancy in gathering or scattering? Thus, those of discernment often find contentment in poverty, awaiting the completion of creation’s design by the Upright Lord.

According to the *Records of Manifesting Sageliness*: In Xuancheng there lived an idle man named Tang Tan, blessed with many children yet content in poverty, fulfilling his allotted fate. His youngest son, Tang Xian, had inherited the ancestral hall’s worship of Zhenwu, the Perfected Warrior, and never once neglected the incense offerings. One day, after winter snow had cleared, a distressed traveler arrived bearing a seated bronze statue of Zhenwu, seeking to sell it to Xian. Xian redeemed it at the offered price, brought it home, and cleansed it with fragrant water. As the grime washed away, the statue revealed itself as pure gold, weighing over fifty taels. Mindful of the price’s inadequacy, Xian, in a daze of devotion, presented it to the authorities. The prefecture, then preparing tribute of money and silk for the imperial court, submitted the statue along with an account of its provenance. The imperial court, upon reviewing the memorial, decreed that the golden statue of Zhenwu, upon entering the inner palace, had radiated a brilliant and auspicious light. Thus, Xuan Prefecture was ordered to disburse five hundred strings of cash from the provincial treasury to Tang Xian as compensation for the gold. Xian accepted the sum and distributed it equally among his brothers, nephews, and sons—Zhongyu, Yuan, and others—each of whom soon established prosperous households. Xian, setting aside his own share, rebuilt the Hall of the Supreme Ultimate at the Taiyi Abbey in gratitude for Zhenwu’s protection and blessings.

Generally, those in straitened circumstances endure their lot, receiving the retribution of this present life. Yet even the coldest valley will know the arrival of spring’s breath. Some men perish in war: if a man holds his rightful place, remains loyal and upright, and dies in fulfillment of the Way, this is a proper end. But those who abandon loyalty to indulge in reckless folly shall surely meet their death amid weapons and severed heads—this is no proper end.

The *Rites of Heavenly Offices* states: "Fine weapons and implements await the state’s great use." Thus, arms are but tools wielded by men. As the *Historical Regulations* verse declares: "Weapons are what the sage employs to punish the violent and pacify a disordered age. Yet when foreign tribes invade the borders or rebels rise within, war becomes inevitable." Heaven is impartial, aiding only those who possess virtue.

Laozi said: "Those who delight in killing cannot achieve their will under Heaven." Have you not heard of the cases of Wang Xian and Chen Chou? The minister Wang Xian, during the early Chunhua era, was sent as an imperial commissioner to govern Dingzhou. One day, a Daoist in tattered robes and a broken cap, his beard bristling like a boar’s, his mouth stretching to his ears, arrived at the official hall to request an audience. He announced: "I oversee affairs at the Fengdu Abbey. Yesterday, I received an edict from the Highest Emperor, ordering the delivery of twenty thousand wandering souls. I have yet to record them in the register of the dead. Whether they live or die now rests with you. If you choose to kill them, though your fame and merit will resound in the celestial bureaus, your own lifespan will be shortened by a decade." Wang dismissed him as a madman, refused to listen, and angrily drove him away.

Soon after, Khitan forces invaded the borderlands, and the Liangmen Fortress stood besieged for many days. As snow fell and the enemy troops grew weary, Wang seized the moment of their unpreparedness and launched a night attack, capturing and routing them. The next day, he executed the prisoners beside the mound of skulls, tallying twenty thousand heads. Only then did Wang regret his decision, but the deed could not be undone. When he reported the victory to the court, he was richly rewarded and promoted to the post of Minister of War. Yet within ten days, he suddenly died.

*The Record of Divine Manifestations* states:

During the Song dynasty, Minister of Revenue Chen Chou was appointed to Yue Prefecture when he suddenly received an imperial summons to return to the capital—a matter that aroused considerable suspicion. Chen personally visited the Qianming Abbey, ascended the Hall of Zhenwu, and burned incense to divine by lot. He drew the fourth slip from the Yellow True Lord, its words refined and elegant. He then sought the interpretation of Yang Fang, the diviner at the Temple of Great Yu.

Yang Fang declared: "You are destined to be granted a military commission to suppress the rampant demonic hordes in the northeast. This lot is no auspicious omen. If you go, the portent will manifest within one hundred and twenty days—you are fated for a violent death." Chen, dismayed, had Yang Fang imprisoned on a forced confession to await verification.

Upon arriving at court, Chen was indeed appointed as the Pacification Commissioner of Nazhou, entrusted with military command to quell the bandit forces of Hu E Mountain in Qizhou, who had plundered the region under He Qing’s leadership. As soon as Chen took command, he was ambushed by raiders in the night. His forces scattered in panic, and he plunged into a ravine, helpless to resist. Suddenly, lightning split the darkness, revealing a long-haired deity wielding a sword who beckoned to Chen. Unaware, Chen found himself mounted alongside the spirit, both restored to the path. Gradually, the people returned, and the camp was reestablished. After several days of battle, He Qing and his followers were captured.

Chen detailed the events in a memorial to the throne and submitted Yang Fang’s divination as corroboration. The Three Departments reviewed the case and specially awarded Yang Fang an official post with monthly stipends to oversee the incense offerings at the Temple of Great Yu. The court dispatched an imperial envoy to present sacred incense at the Qianming Abbey and perform a grand rite of thanksgiving for Zhenwu’s divine intervention.

Those who delight in killing meet swift retribution in shortened lives and death, while Chen, though cast into the jaws of death, was spared. The Most High has said: "To wrongfully kill is to invite the blade of war to claim lives in turn. Some women, through illicit unions or abortions, harm living beings. A woman’s proper place is within the home; by cherishing purity, the inner chambers remain orderly and upright." *The Family Sayings of Confucius* states: "A man is capped at twenty, a woman betrothed at fifteen—only then are the Dao united and transformation complete, for destiny begins with this bond. Husband and wife are bound by heavenly principle, as father and son are. To neglect conduct and propriety, to deceive in secret, to seduce widows and abandoned women, to engage in clandestine affairs—such acts lead women astray. Swayed by private desires, they secretly conceive, then conceal their pregnancies, only to resort to burial or disposal. Unmindful of karmic consequences, heedless of retribution, they employ deceit at the moment of birth to silence gossip—such cases are legion.

Moreover, the penal code forbids the scandal of men and women mingling without distinction, to curb licentiousness and disorder. Yet some masters engage in illicit relations with their maidservants; when the servant conceives, whether the child is raised or not depends on the mistress’s whim. If she denies the servant proper care during childbirth, leading to her death, not only the mistress but the master who fathered the child share the guilt. Others, burdened by many children, casually abandon them. Though they may evade earthly law, unseen retribution draws near, and ghostly reckoning follows.

Have you not heard of Yingniang and the daughter of Wang Yaochen, or the cautionary tale of Ji Kexin’s daughter? There was a woman named Yingniang, a streetwalker weary of pregnancy and resentful of her many children. She repeatedly induced abortions in secret. Once more with child, she took drugs to expel the fetus, but the blood flowed uncontrollably. For six years, she lay bedridden, tormented by a thousand afflictions. One day, her family clearly saw several infants in swaddling clothes, their jade-like limbs writhing as they cried, "We demand our lives!" Only then did Yingniang’s breath cease.

According to *The Records of Puzhou*, Ji Kexin had a daughter named Yinfeng who fell ill and entered the underworld. After several days, she revived and told her father: "At first, two officials escorted me into a city. On either side stood numerous compounds, each gate bearing a placard. I saw one enclosure where countless sinners—men bound and forced to embrace a blazing bronze pillar, women pressed against a massive iron grill—were overseen by ox-headed and horse-faced guards wielding halberds. The moment they were thrust forward, their cries of agony were unbearable. Unable to watch, I asked the attending official, who replied, ‘This is the retribution for those who indulged in lust and destroyed life in their past existence.’

Later, they led me to a hall where a king sat enthroned, flanked by purple-robed officials. Soon, many women burdened with infants were dragged in, their wails rising as they cried for justice. The king questioned them without pause, and in an instant, their fates were sealed. I heard that such retribution in the afterlife determines the separation of loved ones, poverty, suffering, the severing of lineage, and the consequences of debauchery." Ji Kexin recorded her words as a warning to the world.

*The Record of Divine Manifestations* further relates: Wang Yaochen, a Supervisor of the Ministry of Revenue in Shuzhou, had a daughter who conceived out of wedlock. For two years, she did not give birth. Distressed, Wang ordered two maidservants to monitor her for misconduct. Shamed by the scrutiny, the girl fled to the garden and hanged herself. Suddenly, a voice from the void rebuked her: "A woman must not wrongfully discard her life!" The maidservants, hearing this, rushed to save her, cutting the rope and carrying her back. Wang, astonished, summoned the Daoist Chen Juxun of the Lingxian Abbey to report the matter and invoke the protection of Zhenwu at the family shrine.

During the ritual, the girl’s spirit suddenly possessed the deity and confessed her past sins: "In a former life, I was a medicine woman who secretly sold poison to induce abortions, wrongfully taking noble lives. For this crime, the Celestial Emperor was enraged and condemned me to endure humiliation in this life—my womb filled with toxic qi as if pregnant. Now, by the grace of the Supreme Perfected, I was spared from hanging and a worse rebirth." With these words, she revived. Wang Yaochen then performed a grand rite of thanksgiving to Zhenwu and disseminated the tale as a warning to the world.

*The Chapter on the Generation of Spirits* states: "To be reborn in the human realm, to be cleansed by the radiance of the Great Yang, is a blessing beyond measure. What grievance have you against such a fate that you would recklessly take life, abandon children, or resent their abundance?"

Those who frequently appear in litigation halls should heed Laozi’s words: *"To know the constant is called illumination; not knowing it leads to reckless action and misfortune."* This refers to cunning deceit. Those who repeatedly engage in lawsuits and enter official courts—do they not resort to coercion, oppression, or overbearing force to prevail? Confucius said: *"In hearing litigation, I am no different from others. What truly matters is to ensure there is no litigation at all."*

Generally, only when officials are upright and wise can they discern right from wrong, render just decisions, and settle disputes—thus silencing both parties. If they are corrupt and foolish, abandoning the law for bribes, shielding the obstinate, or colluding with crafty clerks, the wronged will harbor grievances with no recourse. Alas, they do not realize that every law and statute is overseen by the celestial and terrestrial bureaus, the water offices, and the underworld. Punishment is administered in both the seen and unseen realms, with governance unified in principle—retribution leaves not the slightest deviation.

*The Divine Decrees of Lan Sheng* states: *"Serve your lord with diligence, govern with earnest care, shun ill-gotten wealth, turn a deaf ear to wicked schemes, rectify judicial errors, and succor the people. Act in accord with the kingly Way, and you shall be a fortunate person. Accumulate transgressions, and you invite calamity—even descent into the depths."*

*The Record of Blessings* recounts: I was once summoned to the netherworld and encountered a fellow townsman, Yu Bing, who wore a cangue while two underworld officers detained him. Weeping, he pleaded with me: *"In life, I forcibly encroached upon my neighbor Zhang Xian’s vacant land by three feet to build a drainage ditch for my eaves. Zhang Xian repeatedly sued me, but to no avail, and the matter faded with time. Now, in the underworld, he has brought suit against me, and I must accept my guilt. Yet I have no way to inform my son—he has drifted to Jianchang, while Zhang Xian’s son has moved to Shaanfu. The paths of the living and the dead are sundered. Now, by fortune, you return to the world. I beg you to convey this message with urgency: compel my son to swiftly cede the land, that I may be released. Otherwise, I shall remain bound here forever."* Upon reviving, I fulfilled his request, and the tale spread through the world.

*The Records of Qi Sheng* document the case of Qian Ju, a commoner from Caizhou, who falsely accused his own brother of being unrelated by blood, denying him a share of their family’s tens of thousands in assets. He bribed officials, and his brother’s lawsuit was suppressed. The matter was later referred to the Imperial Censorate, which dispatched Xu Yi, the Vice Prefect of Xuzhou, to Caizhou to establish a prison and conduct an inquest. The investigating officer, Yang Zhonghe, had accepted Qian Ju’s bribes and fabricated evidence, altering the testimony of the witness Zhu Xijie to frame the innocent. Xu Yi, reckless and negligent, failed to investigate thoroughly and sentenced Zhu Xijie to thirteen strokes of the arm-caning, unjustly severing his case. After Xu Yi’s term ended, his performance review stalled, so he visited the Tianqing Abbey and commissioned the Daoist priest Pei Junshi to submit a petition for divine aid in securing a promotion.

Late into the night, Pei burned the petition before the altar and remained in vigil until the fourth watch. He then addressed Xu Yi: *"When I reached the Gate of the Three Heavens, I saw the Northern Emperor leading Zhenwu inside to memorialize your improper handling of Qian Ju’s case in Caizhou. The Celestial Decree declared: ‘Xu Yi’s petition is to remain here. I fear the Register of the Golden Script will summon you for questioning, and your response will surely err—this bodes grave peril.’ I immediately returned."* Xu Yi, struck with terror, soon died.

The investigating officer, Yang Zhonghe, was so shaken that he resigned his post, distributed his wealth, and devoted himself to charity, boldly amending his ways. When his fortune was exhausted, he subsisted on porridge, and at death, his body dissolved in transcendence. Zhenwu recruited him to serve as the Registrar of Official Appointments in the Eastern Marchmount’s Yama Bureau. The matter reached the Celestial Throne, and an edict was issued conferring upon Yang Zhonghe the title *Wuben Fu Jun* ("Lord Who Awakened to the Origin"). A shrine was erected for him in Xuzhou, where people now pay reverence.

To pervert right into wrong and punish the innocent is to violate the law for personal gain, emboldening litigious scoundrels. To sever kinship and corrupt moral teachings—how can one not fear the true overseers of heaven and earth? When the Celestial Emperor metes out punishment, how will you escape?

At every turn, one sinks into the Sea of Suffering. "Every" signifies each and every affair. "Sinking" denotes the obscuring of one’s conduct and concealment. "Suffering" is the self-inflicted torment. "Sea" is a metaphor for the boundless affairs of the living world. The *Yuan Dong Yu Li Zhang* states: "The Sea of Suffering is likened to a burning house that ensnares worldly people, who, bound by delusion and attachment, form bonds with wayward companions, unaware of the turning of kalpas. They delight only in the pleasures of the multitude, yet find no true peace. Fire, born of the friction of wood, transforms into a sea of scorching agony."

The Buddha spoke of the four conditioned states—love as a condition for love, birth as a condition for birth, aging, sickness, and death—as the torments of boiling affliction. To emerge and vanish, to be entangled and disturbed, to rise and sink—this is the vast sea of the world. The Venerable Taihua said: "By reversing profit, by distinguishing high and low, by ordering before and after, by discerning noble and base, by recognizing decline and prosperity—without clinging, without attachment, without greed, without desire—one who can uphold this is as if riding a raft to cross the surging waves."

The *Scripture of Purity* states: "The reason sentient beings do not attain the true Dao is because of deluded thoughts. Once deluded thoughts arise, the spirit is startled. Once the spirit is startled, one becomes attached to the myriad things. Once attached to the myriad things, craving arises. Once craving arises, it becomes affliction. Affliction and false thoughts distress body and mind, leading to defilement and humiliation, drifting through the cycle of birth and death, forever sinking in the Sea of Suffering, forever losing the true Dao."

Master Bixu said: "Humans are but vessels, all belonging to the dust of the world. The sun and moon race in alternation, forming the cycles of arising and ceasing, the turning of the celestial gate and the earth’s axis, the wheel of rise and fall. Alas, worldly people indulge in the seven emotions and six desires, seeking only the fleeting pleasures of body and mind, giving rein to greed, anger, ignorance, killing, stealing, and lust—how difficult it is to transcend birth and death! Do they ever reflect that in life, their blessings are silently diminished, their years cut short by calamity, and in death, their karmic debts drag them into the hidden depths, where their souls are seized to atone for their sins?"

The *Book of Repentance* states: "North of the human realm lies the vast and foul Qibo Sea, its waters boundless and putrid. Within it stands Mount Fengdu, reaching up to the azure heavens and descending into the winds and springs. At its center lie the Nine Dark Realms, housing thirty-six great hells, established to purge the sins of the dead. The supreme ruler there is the Great Emperor of Fengdu in the Northern Darkness, who oversees all judgments and punishments. This includes the eighteen great Avīci Hells and the twenty-eight constellations’ prisons—all places of confinement and retribution. In these hells, grasses and trees are sharper than swords, fierce beasts capture souls, spewing smoke and fire that scorches the sky without cease. The hellish officials and ghostly clerks, stern and unyielding, torture the imprisoned souls—how could they show mercy?"

The Supreme Lord established these hellish realms as the place where one’s deeds in life receive their due retribution. The *Record of the Divine Manifestation* recounts: "Zhenwu ascended to the Grand Pure Realm to pay homage to his original master, the Most High Lord Lao. The Lord said: 'I have tasked you with subduing the demons of the world and bringing peace to the cosmos. Yet sentient beings still rush headlong into the wheel of rebirth, passing through hell. You must universally deliver them. Bestow blessings upon the good, transform the wicked with goodness, and further cultivate your own fruition.' Zhenwu reverently obeyed and composed a verse: 'When sentient beings cultivate goodness, they become as one with me. When I attain the fruit of realization, it is also due to their good causes.' Having recited this verse, he knelt to take his leave and returned to his post, leaving behind this admonition for the world: 'To cultivate the Dao of immortality, first cultivate the Dao of humanity. The Dao of humanity consists of reverence, humility, kindness to all, compassion, gentleness, benefiting others, aiding the living, devotion to uprightness, frugality in serving parents, practicing benevolence and righteousness, performing acts of kindness, restraining arrogance, not relying on power, pitying the orphaned and widowed, extending compassion—this is the Dao of humanity. If one cannot even cultivate the Dao of humanity, how much farther is the Dao of immortality?'"

To squander one’s estate: Scholars receive fields to offer sacrifices, and commoners farm to feed themselves, relying on the transformations of the four seasons and the abundance of the five grains. Even a single measure of beans is allotted by fate. Yet some, though their fields stretch across the countryside and their granaries overflow, still covet the fertile lands of others. Mozi said: "It is not that there is no secure dwelling, but that there is no secure heart." Laozi said: "No misfortune is greater than insatiable desire." The *Scripture of Responding to the Times* states: "In the world to come, sentient beings will be benighted and unable to awaken. They will seek distant gains, forcibly amass wealth, and strive to enrich their descendants for generations, encroaching upon lands to build mansions—this is cultivating karma to await its retribution."

Generally, the measure of one’s fields and blessings is decreed by heaven, with abundance or scarcity naturally determined. How could one greedily seize what is not theirs? To falsely accuse a woman of squandering her estate is to accumulate the sinful qi of complacency and arrogance. The celestial overseers take note, and this sin of covetousness will erase your fields and homes from the registers, visibly dissolving your estate.

The *Exhortation of the Dark Emperor* states: "With a tranquil body and mind, no disasters or defilements arise. Cherishing things and exploring nature, one remains naturally free from illness. Discerning the wise and foolish, the dull-witted will naturally vanish. Illuminated and clear-sighted, worldly entanglements diminish. If one’s mind is empty and spiritually attuned, what trace of reality remains? Coming and going, the essence of qi ascends. Thunder, lightning, and mighty storms—all the people of the world witness them. Swift retribution is manifest, clearly revealed in the heavens. Do not obscure your original heart, nor indulge in excessive divination. Cherish your kin, live in harmony like springtime. Treat neighbors as family, reduce greed and increase affection. Rescue the distressed, aid the poor, be loyal, sincere, and frugal. Cleanse away obstinate dust, live in harmony and joy. Uphold purity and guard clarity, and the divine will bless your wishes. Your lifespan will be unharmed, and your descendants will thrive. In life, you will avoid the fetters of suffering and calamity; in death, you will escape the clamor of the underworld’s trials. Today, I write this universal exhortation. May those who gaze upon it be spared from misfortune. If one copies ten scrolls and posts them in all directions, plagues and pestilences will not dare appear. But if fools, in their anger, slander my words, their souls will be seized and sent straight to Fengdu for punishment."

Dissipating wealth and resources is to be avoided.

The most urgent task in managing one’s fate is securing clothing and food, for these depend on wealth to sustain the body and nourish the household. *Master Zhuang* said: "If wealth is not accumulated, those who rely on it will suffer. Seeking riches through strange or improper means is merely a path to temporary abundance." *Master Mo* said: "It is not that there is insufficient wealth, but that the heart lacks contentment." *Confucius* said: "Wealth and honor are what all people desire, yet if they are obtained by improper means, one should not dwell in them." *Laozi* said: "No misfortune is greater than not knowing contentment," and further: "Knowing contentment brings no disgrace."

The *Scripture of the Void Sovereign* states: "Wealth is the root of sustenance. Accumulating wealth is like accumulating karma, for wealth is the root of desire and can give rise to all sins. Hoarding excessively leads only to ruin." Yet people remain ignorant of this. The ghostly enforcer Pei Pu once dreamed of his friend Wei Yuanfang, who said: "I oversee the daily expenditures of the world—every sip, every bite, every resource—all are recorded, and their acquisition is limited. Should one take even a single item or coin beyond what is allotted, I command legions of ghostly soldiers to seize it. This matter falls under the jurisdiction of the Fengdu Court’s *Zhoujue Yintian* General Bureau, which governs the confiscation of ill-gotten wealth. We dispatch spirits from the original cavern to be reborn into such households, waiting for the appointed time to dissipate their wealth."

According to the *Scripture of Blessing and Protection*, the *Perfected One Who Preserves Life* said: "Do not harm the worthy with malice, lest Heaven send misfortune. Do not disrespect parents, lest Heaven grow angry. Do not slander the sages, lest Heaven bring disaster. Do not covet unjust gain, lest Heaven diminish you. Do not harm others, lest Heaven cast you down. Do not injure others, lest Heaven repay you in kind."

The *Divine Edicts of the Dark Emperor* state: "Those who falsely seek glory will find their reputation unspread. Those who amass wealth through exploitation will leave calamity for their descendants. Those who practice kindness and bestow virtue will see fortune and blessings take flight. Those who restrain desire and moderate their diet will enjoy long life. Do not deceive in darkness, nor obscure the Three Luminaries. Be upright and selfless, loyal and true of heart. Heaven and Earth will intercede, and the divine will stand guard at your side. To extend life and overcome hardship, one must surely bring peace to the times. Yet if misfortune arises, it is by one’s own fault. As *Tai Jia* said: 'If Heaven brings disaster, it may yet be avoided. But if one brings disaster upon oneself, there is no escape.' Wherever the divine generals reside, fierce demons lower their heads, and evil ways flee in terror."

In any place where halls or temples are built for the sacred image of the Dark Emperor, or where households display his likeness, jealous spirits and fierce demons, upon hearing the name of the true overseers, will cower in submission. Should they stir up misfortune or evil, they will vanish at the sight of the divine banners. Thus, those who revere him will find fortune rising like clouds, while calamity scatters like lightning.

As the *Book of Songs* says: "Illuminating service to the Highest Emperor brings abundant blessings." The *Instructions of the Soaring Sage* state: "Offer incense with reverence to the lofty heavens, guard your nature and refine your being within. If you can embody this sincerity, blessings will naturally follow, fortune and felicity will pursue you, and auspicious qi will arise."

Auspicious qi manifests in five forms: the first is *qingyun*, the "cloud of fortune," seen as a joyful omen and the harbinger of blessings. It gathers the Five Fortunes, and a hundred blessings will descend upon your body. Fortune is the smooth progression of affairs; what is harmonious is called fortune. The *Scripture of the Northern Dipper* says: "When true qi descends from the five directions, ten thousand blessings naturally converge." *Converge* means to gather as one. It further states: "Dispel the Three Disasters and Nine Calamities, and ensure peace in this present spring."

The *Book of Documents* says: "Only Heaven sends down disasters; auspiciousness lies in virtue." The *Scripture of Salvation* states: "Ten thousand calamities will not approach; divine protectors will guard your gate. Thunder and lightning, celestial soldiers, and scribes will always accompany you, dispersing disasters and anomalies."

You have earnestly inquired, and so I reveal this mechanism, tracing the subtle origins of the Dao’s records to bring great blessings to the people of Heaven. Though my words are brief, I wish for you to understand them clearly. Were I not a perfected being, this knowledge would rightfully remain secret.

The Dark Emperor spoke to Miao Xing, saying: "Do you have karmic affinity from past lives that prompts your earnest questions today?" The *Dao’s records* refer to the years of transmission and ordination, used to verify the subtle origins of the Dark Warrior’s mysteries. Those who faithfully uphold them are called the *People of Heaven*, who receive great blessings.

*Master Zhuang* said: "Those who cultivate themselves are now as they have always been—constant and unwavering. When people align with them, Heaven aids them. Those whom people abandon are called the People of Heaven." According to the *True Instructions of Supreme Clarity*: "People born into the world who do not cultivate the Dao are no different from grasses, trees, birds, or beasts—they are called ordinary people. Among ordinary people, those who awaken and set their minds on cultivation, seeking long life, may study these essential scriptural teachings. Then, the mysteries we practice will become clear to them."

*Master Zhuang* said: "Those who do not depart from the true are called *perfected beings*." *Master Xun* said: "One who understands the distinction between Heaven and humanity may be called a *perfected being*." Without such understanding, how could one be called *perfected*? Consider the case of Han Yuanshou: though he meditated deeply in seclusion and recited scriptures diligently, his focus was not single-minded. One day, heavenly fire burned his house, and his scriptures flew into the sky. After ninety years, Yuanshou transformed into a tree spirit. If even such a man faced such retribution, how much more severe will be the consequences for those today who treat transmission lightly?

Thus concludes *The Wondrous Scripture of the Dark Emperor of the Primordial Heaven, the Perfected Martial Sage, with Divine Spells and Origins*, Scroll Four.

The Perfected of all Blessed Lands shall each heed the Jade Emperor’s rotational assignments and accept their appointed duties. Their governance, merits, and faults shall be subject to review for promotion or demotion.

The boundless *Flying Heavenly Deities*, the *Infinite Long-Life Great Sages*, the *Golden Lads and Jade Maidens*, the *Nine Phoenixes and Eight Luan Birds*—all stand radiant in attendance, arrayed to left and right. "Boundless" signifies the immeasurable; "infinite," the unfathomable; "limitless," the ultimate. Such is the innumerable host of attendants.

Moreover, beneath the celestial palaces of all heavens, the ranks of courtiers, officials, and functionaries stand in solemn array. The *Flying Heavenly Deities* serve as the scribes and chariot-drivers of the celestial bureaucracy, overseeing ritual regalia and sacred implements. As the *Great Precepts Sutra* states: "Those of old who mastered the precepts, cultivated diligent practice, and never regressed were acknowledged as pure and faithful adepts. Upon the fulfillment of their destiny and the end of their lives, they were specially appointed as *Flying Heavenly Deities* of valor in the heavens."

The *Long-Life Great Sages* are ministers who oversee the Three Departments, recording the merits of cultivation across the Three Realms. According to the *Jade Dawn’s Hidden Basket*: "For disciples of the Lower Realm caught in the swift cycles of pestilence, if their hearts depart from worldly darkness and their resolve remains unshaken, their spiritual powers and wisdom reach their zenith, and the radiance of Dharma, spirit, and wisdom pierces the heavens—thus entering the Dao of true constancy—they shall be welcomed by celestial immortals. By imperial decree, they are appointed to the ranks of celestial officials, presiding over the registers of life."

The *Golden Lads* hold the office of *Marquis of Peaceful Village*, akin to the *Attendant Gentleman of the Palace* in the mortal realm. As the *House Biographies of the Han Celestial Masters* records: "Zifang and Ziyuan both served as lads in the *Supreme Clarity Palace*, attending the *Venerable Lord*."

The *Jade Maidens* fulfill roles as messengers of refined virtue, comparable to imperial consorts and court ladies. According to the *Primal Chaos Sutra*: "From the primordial *qi*, clouds coalesced into pavilions. Through breath and invocation, numinous talismans transformed into light, and *Golden Lads and Jade Maidens* bore standards and canopies."

The *Phoenixes and Luan Birds* are sacred fowl, originating from the *Cinnabar Cavern* and *Female Bathing* mountains in the Southern Sea. The *Nine Phoenixes*—nine forming a single flock—are styled as such, serving the *Three Clarities*. Together, they number eighty-one, and their movements compose the *Nine Shao* melodies, harmonizing with the music of the *Jade Clarity*, *Supreme Clarity*, and *Great Clarity* heavens. The *Eight Luan Birds*—eight forming a single flock—are styled as such, numbering sixty-four in total. Their dances align with the *Eight Refined Movements*, complementing the rites of the *Cavern of Perfection*, *Cavern of Mystery*, and *Cavern of Divinity*. These birds stand eight or nine *chi* tall, their plumage resplendent, their radiance undiminished until the dance’s end. Thereafter, they encircle the heavens, standing guard to left and right. The *Eight Sounds* resonate spontaneously, and all the sages rejoice.

The *Eight Sounds* refer to the harmonies of instruments shaped by the Eight Trigrams. "Spontaneous resonance" arises when the divine wind stirs the *qian* forest, producing tones. Only in the Three Realms and Nine Heavens does the wondrous *self-sounding celestial music* emerge—from the branches and leaves of *linlang* jewel-trees—each note a marvel of *gong* and *shang* cadence. There are the chimes of jade and stone, the rhythms of drums and *kan* leather, the melodies of *sheng* reeds and *gen* gourds, the flutes of *zhen* bamboo, the strikes of *xun* and *yu* wood, the strumming of *qin* and *se* strings, the tunes of *xun* and *fou* clay, and the clangs of *rao* cymbals and *dui* metal. As the *Numinous Treasure Sutra* declares:
*"The towering realm of the Jade Palace stands,
With forests of blossoms swaying in grace.
The divine wind stirs the cavern’s echo,
Ensuring boundless years in this place."*

This sublime music, resounding with natural clarity, most benefits those who hear it, preserving their true nature in its entirety. Thus, all in attendance rejoice in its beauty.

Now, hearken solemnly to the *Celestial Worthy* expound the wondrous Dharma of the *Utmost Perfection*. "Hearken solemnly" signifies the reverent attention of the assembly to the discourse. The *Dharma of the Utmost Perfection* is the esoteric scripture of the *Middle Vehicle of the Cavern of Mystery*, which initiates the Nine Perfected of the heavens.

This teaching comprises twelve divisions, each with its own hierarchy:
1. *Numinous Harmony Division*
2. *Numinous Treasure Division*
3. *Spirit Communication Division*
4. *Boundless Division*
5. *Immortal Assembly Division*
6. *Inner Esoteric Division*
7. *Utmost Perfection Division*
8. *Virtue Cultivation Division*
9. *Essence Refinement Division*
10. *Life Portal Division*
11. *Officials and Charts Division*
12. *Demon Subjugation Division*

Together, these divisions encompass eighty-four thousand scrolls. The *Primal Beginning* bestowed them upon the *Jade Dawn Great Dao Lord*, sealing them eternally within the *Jade Capital Heavenly Terrace* of the *Mystic Metropolis*. Their texts are complete across the Thirty-Six Heavens. Though the immortals of sacred mountains, grotto-heavens, seas, and peaks may engage in cultivation, they have only heard of these divisions’ titles—how could they fully attain this vehicle? Even less so for the scholars and common folk of the lower realms. The scriptures now disseminated in the world derive from the second division: the wondrous *Numinous Treasure Unfolding Charts Sutra*.

The *Sutra of Responding to the Era* records the words of an elder from the Western Regions: "Generally, all wonders converge in a single gateway. If mortals inwardly align with the cyclical movements of *yin* and outwardly embody the firmness and softness of *yang*, guiding them through the Five Constants and receiving them in a single *qi*—within this gateway, they may discern the gradual path. Thus, the spirit-*qi* descends and stills. Once the spirit is stilled, the hundred demons retreat in silence. This is the numinous Dharma, wherein all *qi* are harmonized. When *qi* is harmonized and still, the Four Great Elements become pure—this is the alchemical transformation, the Great Treasure."

The *Dao-qi* is purified, encircling the *Supreme Mystery*. "Purified" denotes the solemn and pristine *qi* of the Utmost Dao. Thus, clarity and radiance coalesce into the sovereign of spiritual transformation. The flowing secrets of the *Cavern Precepts* ascend to the *Supreme Clarity* and encompass the *Cavern of Divinity* below—this is the encircling of the *Supreme Mystery*. As the *Numinous Treasure Unfolding Charts Sutra* states: "The *Primal Beginning* employed the ancestral *qi* of the *Numinous Treasure*, merging it with the *Primordial Azure Qi* to govern the heavens, earth, ghosts, and spirits, nurturing the world. The *qi* of life embraces the soul, refining and safeguarding the Great Harmony, permeating the Lower Realm and its people."

At that time, the Primordial Beginning commanded the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign, inscribing with a purple brush to record and expand the Great Teaching, that its compassionate grace might flow forth and guide learners. According to the Western Venerable Elder: "The Supreme Mystery descends to the subtle, responding to the turning of the celestial pivot. The Flower Chamber governs the assembly of *qi*, while the Purple Palace gathers numinous might." This is the essential Dao of returning to truth, the gateway and window to penetrating the Mystery.

When a superior adept first ascends to the *Numinous Treasure*, beginning to knock at the gate of the Mysterious Principle, one must be led and guided—this method responds to the moment, seeking the return to the abode. Only then may the wondrous principles be studied with precision. "Only then" refers to the methods of the *Numinous Treasure*'s wondrous principles. The Primordial Heavenly Worthy, for the sake of all, expounded the subtle and profound, so that the myriad sages might delve deeply into its ultimate essence.

The Left Immortal Elder elucidated the *Numinous Treasure*'s precept-methods: The *Numinous Treasure*'s original *qi* was at first a singular undifferentiated whole. From the source-stream of the Great Void, it ascended and descended through the various heavens. Its numinous efficacy pervaded the distant and subtle, aiding and sheltering the host of immortals. Auspicious omens flourished in luxuriance, bestowing ranks and conferring perfect grace. By spirit descending and gathering, it became the forerunner of the Daoist method. By *qi* settling and stilling, it accorded with spontaneity.

In the northeast of the Heavenly Gate, the ancestral *qi* unfolded its transformations, and the ninefold heavens arrayed the thirty-six heavens. The utmost above is called the Great Loftiness; the three realms of heaven are the capital heavens. Between the capital heaven and the northeast gate lies what is named the *Supreme Clarity of the Eight Effulgences*, the *Primordial Azure Heaven*. The Primordial Beginning often expounded the great *Numinous Treasure* teachings within this heaven, which covers the northeast of the lower realm, above the ghostly paths of the wilds.

When the *Sublime Scripture of Salvation for Humanity, Supreme Grade* was proclaimed, the myriad sages all assembled in the *Primordial Azure Heaven* to receive the Primordial Beginning’s boundless, supreme salvation for humanity. Seven great sounds shook the heavens, and ten eyes gazed as one, beholding the karmic demons of the lower world and the foul *qi* surging toward the heavens. The host of perfected ones fell silent, and the Great Dao became still.

The "seven sounds" refer to the seven emotions of the mortal realm—joy, anger, sorrow, happiness, worry, resentment, and thought. The innocent suffer curses and punishments, crying out to heaven in anguish, their bitter suffering startling the celestial audience. As the saying goes: "Whispers among men are heard in heaven like thunder"—this is what is meant by the great shaking.

At that assembly, ten eyes gazed as one upon the lower realm, where the four kinds of birth endured kalpas, their forms and lives transformed, their inner and outer *qi* exhausted in cycles. As the *Record of Rites* states: "What ten eyes see and ten hands point to is most severe"—this expresses the depth of their concern. Thus, the multitudes of the ten directions fell silent in unison, mourning the sentient beings.

Reverently contemplating the Great Dao, the Primordial Beginning, the Most High, remained motionless and silent, yet responsive and all-pervading. According to the *Numinous Treasure Repentance*: At that time, the Primordial August Thearch emitted a divine radiance to illuminate below, revealing the demonic hosts of the Six Heavens—*Kejia* and their ilk—marching through the mortal world, entangling the living and the seven generations of deceased ancestors, forming cliques to act with wanton violence. Their conflicts and slaughters knew no day or night, leaving corpses and bloodshed strewn about. The *qi* of resentment and wails of sorrow transformed into toxic *qi*, surging against the celestial radiance.

Then the Wondrous Conduct Perfected One, hearing of this before the Primordial Beginning, asked: "Having expounded the wondrous Dharma and assembled auspicious signs, what is this strange cause that now intrudes? May you bestow profound guidance to resolve the doubts of the assembly." At that moment, the Wondrous Conduct Perfected One, unaware of the reason for these strange omens, posed this question, seeking clarification.

The Primordial Beginning is the Most Honored among the myriad heavens, the sovereign of the unsurpassed Dharma. Having expounded the wondrous Dharma, he constantly saves and delivers all, harmonizing extraordinary auspices. Why, then, did this strange cause intrude before the Primordial Beginning’s presence? The Wondrous Conduct Perfected One, perplexed, respectfully entreated the Purple Tenuity Great Emperor to reveal the profound meaning of the past, resolving the doubts of the great assembly.

The Great Emperor replied: "The people of the Lower Realm all receive the Ultimate Dao, endowed with the pure *qi* of primordial chaos to support and protect their mortal bodies. All embodied forms belong to the Lower Realm, governed by the Three *Qi* Lords. Each is imbued with the *Numinous Treasure*'s Ultimate Dao, the natural flow of primordial chaotic *qi* permeating and sustaining the creation of male and female bodies."

According to the *Various Scriptures*: The *Numinous Treasure*'s *Primordial Azure Qi* coalesces into the *Original Yang*, weighing three hundred eighty-four *zhu*, establishing the *qi* of life that falls into the void and sings through the channels. It courses through the meridians and vessels, corresponding to the three hundred sixty bones and limbs. The *qi* of the Great Floating Black Earth coalesces and transforms, cycling through yellow, white, azure, and red to conceive and congeal essence. The *Original One Yellow Evolved Qi* forms the placenta. The *Cavern Obscurity Purple Portal Qi* shapes the embryo. The *Numinous Brightness Immortal Qi* commands the hun-soul. The *Vast Corpse Obscure Evolved Qi* commands the po-soul. The *Five Immortals Central Numinous Qi* forms the viscera. The *Lofty Perfected Harmonious Qi* forms the bowels. The *Lofty Immortal Cavern Tome Qi* forms the origin. The *True Numinous Coalescing Qi* binds the flower. The *Spontaneous Mysterious Illumination Qi* binds the peaks. The *Jade Clarity Chaotic Obscurity Qi* transforms the mud-pill. The *Supreme Clarity Crimson Chaos Qi* transforms the Crimson Palace. The *Great Clarity Mysterious Pervasion Qi* transforms the Cinnabar Field.

The *Blazing Deluder*'s three *qi* descend as true fire, entering the heart and exiting the tongue, governing the warmth of the spirit-*qi*. The *Year Star*'s nine *qi* descend as true wood, entering the liver and exiting the eyes, governing the skin, hair, and body hair. The *Quelling Star*'s one *qi* descends as true earth, entering the spleen, stomach, and mouth, governing the flesh and four limbs. The *Great White*'s seven *qi* descend as true metal, entering the lungs and exiting the nose, governing the teeth and sinews. The *Chronos Star*'s five *qi* descend as true water, entering the kidneys and exiting the ears, governing the fluids, blood, and marrow.

The *qi* of the seven eastern asterisms governs the *Yang Brightness* meridian. The *qi* of the seven southern asterisms governs the *Greater Yang* meridian. The *qi* of the seven western asterisms governs the *Lesser Yin* meridian. The *qi* of the seven northern asterisms governs the *Greater Yin* meridian. The Azure Numinous Emperor Lord of the Eastern Dipper governs destiny. The White Standard Emperor Lord of the Western Dipper registers names. The Seven Governors of the Northern Dipper oversee the gathering of life.

The Six Governors of the Southern Dipper oversee its movements and functions. The Central Dipper’s *Primordial Numinous Great Emperor* binds and subdues the myriad spirits.

Zhuangzi said: "Humans inherit heaven and follow earth, arranging *qi* to form shape—this is called the numinous essence of beings." The *Scripture of the Northern Dipper* states: "Ordinary mortals in the world, deluded and confused, often do not know their bodies belong to the Northern Dipper, their lives governed by the Celestial Treasury. When disasters and calamities strike, they know not the gate of expiation and gratitude. Seeking to prolong fortune and life, they remain ignorant of the path to return to truth, causing their souls to be bound and misfortunes to accumulate."

The *Divinely Responsive Emperor Lord*, descending with his brush, proclaimed: "By the mandate of the Jade Emperor, I issue this compassionate decree. Moved by the plight of the common people, it is ordained that from the *Ding-Si* year of the Middle Prime Festival onward, all under heaven shall exhort one another to pool resources and establish the *Grand Ritual of the Three Realms, Illuminating Prosperity and Pacifying Clarity*. Those who perform this rite shall be delivered from the turbid waves of the final kalpic conflagration. The ritual protocols shall reverently invite my teachings, and disciples shall propagate the liturgy of the *Supreme Prolongation of Life*. They shall recite scriptures, ascend the altar, and present memorials to heaven and earth."

The *Divinely Responsive Emperor Lord* supervised the *Tai* Mountain Prefecture, where the Three Bureaus inscribed their names. The memorial was then submitted to the Three Celestial Gates, granting deliverance from the kalpic doom. Truly, is there no greater joy than this?

Now, as the kalpic cycle nears its end, demonic forces grow rampant. The *Sutra of Karmic Retribution* states: "At the dawn of each kalpa, it is the *Dragon Han* and *Red Clarity* era. The *Cavern of Truth* descends, and people embrace virtue and power, many attaining longevity. In the mid-kalpa, it is the *Supreme August* and *Prolonged Prosperity* era. The *Cavern of Mystery* descends, and people gradually abandon simplicity, losing the Dao and rebelling against virtue. At the kalpa’s end, it is the *Kaihuang* era’s conclusion. The *Cavern of Spirit* descends, and people grow frivolous, few upholding true rectitude. Heaven’s ordinances falter, and the world endures the three kalpas of *Kaihuang*." After the *Jia-Zi* year of the Upper Prime of the Song dynasty, the seventh *Kaihuang* kalpa began. Alas! In this final kalpa, calamities fill the heavens.

We witness the sun and moon eclipsed and dimmed, the five planets erring in their courses, the six extremes meting out punishments, the four barbarians waging war, fires burning and floods sweeping, droughts and locusts ravaging, frost, hail, and freezing storms descending, lands collapsing and mountains crumbling, serpents and tigers manifesting as omens, excessive punishments and cruel tyranny, human demons and ghostly specters, epidemics and untimely deaths—all named *kalpic retribution*.

The *Western Florescence Emperor Lord* said: "The kalpic cycles of heaven and earth alternate between adversity and prosperity, ending and responding in turn. The great cosmic pattern follows myriad transformations, its cessation and renewal cyclical. Yet the kalpa’s end and beginning are without limit or exhaustion. Only the sentient beings of the turbid world, bound to the kalpa, endure the wheel of rebirth—some facing the kalpa’s doom, some the *qi*-kalpa, some external calamities, some internal afflictions, some bodily tribulations, some fate’s trials. If beings’ primordial karma runs deep and their deeds remain benighted, when they encounter the kalpic realm, they drift like sand in the苦海, adrift and endless. When the kalpa reaches its end, it becomes eternal severance, transforming into the *qi* of dark resentment."

In the *Ding-Si* year of the *Qingyuan* reign, during the Upper Prime Festival, heaven sent down a jade missive to the *Zitong* Divine Temple in Jianzhou. The temple’s warden respectfully submitted the document to the imperial court. According to the report, *Zhang Yazhun*, the *Illustrious Martial and Valiant Numinous Assistant, Vast Salvation and Benevolent Tranquility King*, *Supervisor of the Golden Watchtower of the August Heaven*, *Perfected Master of the Nine Heavens’ Transformative Governance*, and *Zitong Divinely Responsive Emperor Lord*, received a memorial from the Three Celestial Gates via the Three Palace Envoys. It detailed the *Bing-Xu* year’s *Three Realms’ Spiritual Offering Assembly*, concluding the registration of the Lower Prime’s affairs before all departed.

At that time, the *August Jade Emperor of the Vast Heaven* ascended his throne to the *Upper Prime Supreme Unity Palace*. Emerging from the Three Celestial Gates, he surveyed the six directions and eight boundaries below, his gaze all-encompassing. Yet he saw only coils of grievance, wails of sorrow, and the innocent crying out to heaven—voices that pierced the celestial hearing.

The Jade Emperor issued a compassionate decree, addressing his attendant minister, the *Golden Watchtower Censor-in-Chief and Grand Preceptor of the Three Celestial Gates*, *Ge Hong*: "The living beings below—from high-ranking officials and rulers to local magistrates and clerks—enforce harsh laws and exorbitant taxes. Even the powerful families, great households, wealthy merchants, and major traders prioritize bribes in every action, pursuing only profit in all directions. They indulge in feasts, music, and sensual pleasures, disregarding reason, speaking falsely, and behaving like scavenging dogs. They treat parents, teachers, and kin with disdain and arrogance. The rich ignore the poor; the noble disdain the lowly. Marriages are contracted for wealth, alliances forged for worldly gain. They seize from the destitute, exploit the suffering, and refuse aid to the impoverished, driving many to ruin."

The Jade Emperor commanded the *Right Regular Attendant*, *Wang Qiao*, *Orator and Messenger Bearing the Jade Clarity Palace’s Edict*, *Yin Xi*, *Grand Preceptor of the Jade Clarity Palace and Guardian of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure’s Celestial Pivot Institute*, *Xu Jia*, *Grand Preceptor of the Supreme Clarity Palace and Guardian of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure’s Southern Culmen Institute*, *Zhang Daoling*, *Grand Preceptor of the Grand Clarity Palace and Guardian of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure’s Northern Culmen Institute*, the *Celestial August Emperor of the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace*, the *Mysterious Heavenly August Emperor of the Earth*, the *Three Officials Great Emperors of Heaven, Earth, and Water*, the *Four Marshal Sage Emperors*, *Yan Hui*, *Cultivator of Literature in the Celestial Treasury and Duke of Yan*, *Bu Shang*, *Cultivator of Literature in the Earthly Treasury and Duke of Henei*, *Qu Yuan*, *Cultivator of Literature in the Water Treasury and Duke of Qinglie*, the Venerable *Kasyapa*, the Venerable *Ananda*, and the Venerable *Pindola*—eighteen in total—to attend court and present their memorials before the throne.

The Jade Emperor spoke to the assembled ministers: "The living beings of the lower world now face the final kalpa. The Three Teachings are neglected: those who become monks or Daoists often disregard precepts and act without reason; scholars and commoners fail to honor the teachings of the revered Zhou and Confucius; and officials of high rank indulge in excess and corruption."

Moreover, the vast multitudes of living beings, following perverse customs, scorn the hundred grains, crave wealth like starving tigers, and spread poison like raging fire. They abandon the upright and follow the crooked, making such ways habitual and customary—those who transgress shall not be pardoned or absolved.

You, the assembled ministers, shall convene in the Celestial Court on the first day of the first month each year beginning in the *dingsi* year, to examine and record good and evil. Relying upon the numinous power of the Imperial Lords of the Void and the Boundless Realm, you shall first issue written decrees to announce these judgments to the earthly city gods and local deities, and likewise dispatch documents to the courts of the Five Marchmounts and Mount Tai, establishing this as an eternal statute. The Offices of Intent, Manifest Report, and Swift Report shall daily enforce strict scrutiny, transmitting reports in succession to the Celestial Prefecture.

In regions where the people do not follow the Way, do not uphold virtue, or fail to revere and trust in the teachings, retribution shall be measured by their transgressions: pestilence, drought, locusts, thunder and lightning, violent winds, sudden rains, killing frosts, hail, and freezing cold shall damage the hundred grains and deplete the earth’s bounty. The Four Barbarians shall invade, bringing the scourge of war and battle; the earth shall split and mountains collapse; serpents and tigers shall run rampant. Demonic spirits shall be sent to take birth in their households, destroying their foundations and annihilating their kin.

Yet if they reform their conduct, exert themselves in right action, and adhere to the words of the *Tai Shang Gan Ying Pian*, avoiding all enumerated transgressions, their misfortunes shall be transformed into blessings.

Thus is this decree issued. Let all take heed.

From the Three Celestial Gates, the Envoys of the Three Palaces hereby dispatch this document to the Imperial Lord of Numinous Response of Nine-Bend Phoenix Mountain for enforcement.

Those who stray into heterodox paths and neglect the cultivation of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and virtue shall be of this kind.

Those who fail to reflect upon their fundamental origins and resent the teachings and kindness of parents, teachers, and friends are of this kind. Those who delight in worshipping heterodox spirits and indulge in licentious sacrifices to disorderly gods, currying favor with earnest entreaties, are of this kind. Those who obsequiously seek residual blessings and flatter through prayers to uncanny forces, vainly beseeching illusory fortune, are of this kind. Those who sink into confusion and disorder, lost in drunkenness and infatuated with lust, losing all sense of propriety, are of this kind. Those who are avaricious and obstinate, their greed for ill-gotten wealth rooted in overbearing qi, are of this kind.

Those who act without righteousness, harming others for personal gain, are of this kind. Those who lack benevolence, oppressing beings and bullying others, are of this kind. Those who are disloyal, cunning and failing to devote themselves wholeheartedly, are of this kind. Those who are unfilial, deceiving their kin and undermining teachings, are of this kind.

According to the *Lingbao Hunyuan Jiuku Jing*, the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning states: "I observe the sinful souls in the nether realms—those who, from kalpas past to the present, while living as humans, committed myriad transgressions. They failed to reflect upon their fundamental origins, were gluttonous and envious, secretly harmed others while seeking ease for themselves, contended over wealth and qi, indulged in wine and lust, depleted their spirit and dissipated their primordial truth. They were unfilial to their elders, disloyal to their lords, bullied the humble, and treated others with arrogance. Having committed a thousand kinds of sins, they are seized by the Heavenly Officials, their souls pursued by the Star Lords, and sent down to the Nine Dark Realms to endure suffering. Those with lighter offenses are reborn into the Six Paths; those with heavier sins remain imprisoned forever. Even if they regain human form, how can they attain blessings and fortune?

Now, the Six Heavenly Demon Kings and the Five Bureau Plague Offices, disregarding rank, unjustly inflict harm—whether old or young, female or male—cutting short lives before their allotted years, forcing them to depart the world prematurely. Though their deaths were not fated, their souls are left solitary, their resentment surging upward, coiled and unrelenting. Such violent and untimely deaths are truly pitiable."

According to the *Dongyuan Jing*: "In the northern lands of the human realm lies Mount Fengdu, beside the great cavern of the Water Palace, where six palaces stand in array, known as the Six Heavens. They are ruled by the Six Great Demon Kings, the outer Six Bureaus of the Supreme Yin Heavenly Lord. The minor officials of these Six Bureaus number three hundred and sixty thousand, each of grotesque and fearsome form, their bodies forged from the qi of violence and rebellion, roaming the vastness of the void. If a person’s thoughts remain upright and pure, reciting the names of these Six Palaces with reverence, the Six Heavens shall open benevolently, the Demon Kings shall protect and advocate for them, their sins erased, and they shall rely upon this for life and death, gaining boundless fortune. But if a person harbors a single impure desire, the Six Heavens shall open malevolently, and according to the severity of their transgressions, they shall be afflicted with the Six Pains and Five Plagues as retribution."

The First Heaven: *Zhoujue Yin Dong Xiuming Zongyin Dong Yin Gong*, which oversees the penal records and nether prisons of Fengdu, meting out the sins committed in past lives, causing people in this world to squander and dissipate their resources.

The Second Heaven: *Taisha Liangshi Dong Yuan Si Zhong Zheng Si Ling Gong*, which gathers the wandering, violent, and reckless souls of the world, causing people’s fortunes to stagnate and their official ranks and titles to decline.

The Third Heaven: *Mingchen Naifan Wucheng Dong Tong Xian Sheng Ling Xi Wan Gong*, which seizes the blessings and fortunes of the world, where the souls of both sages and commoners, upon departing this life, first pass through this cavern to be processed.

The Fourth Heaven: *Tianzhao Zuiqi Dong Zhengzhen Shaoling Wan Si Gong*, which governs plagues, deaths, disasters, fires, and malevolent spirits, eroding people’s fields and dwellings, draining their yin and extinguishing their yang, bringing forth disputes and official misfortunes.

The Fifth Heaven: *Zongling Qifei Dong Yunyu Yujiming Yuan Gong*, which presides over familial discord, marital strife, separation, and the affairs of widowers and widows.

The Sixth Heaven: *Gansi Lianwan Lü Dong Chongling Chiming Yunqu Gong*, which destroys the male and female offspring of the world, including those conceived in the womb, severing both mother and child, disrupting the succession of heirs.

As for the Five Bureaus, they are the mountain bureaus of the Five Peaks, each establishing plague offices. According to the *Zhengyi Zhuan*: "The plague gods of the Five Bureaus are endowed with the unbalanced qi of the Five Phases, manifesting in countless numbers to roam the human realm, exhaling poison and howling calamity. When they travel east, they are called Demon Kings; when west, Heterodox Ways; when south, Ghost Commanders; when north, Ghost Kings; and within the Central Realm, Plague Gods."

The Eastern Peak, Mount Tai, is governed by the Heavenly Equal Benevolent Sage Emperor, who oversees miscellaneous illnesses through Liu Yuanda. The Southern Peak, Mount Heng, is governed by the Celestial Bright Sage Emperor, who oversees plagues through Zhang Yuanbo. The Western Peak, Mount Hua, is governed by the Metal Heavenly Compliant Sage Emperor, who oversees dysentery through Zhao Gongming. The Northern Peak, Mount Heng, is governed by the Peaceful Heavenly Primordial Sage Emperor, who oversees violent sweats and malarial chills through Shi Wenye. The Central Peak, Mount Song, is governed by the Central Heavenly Revered Sage Emperor, who administers illnesses through four bureaus: Li Gongshen for madness and red-eyed specters; Zhong Shiji for swellings and sores; Fan Zhongqing for emaciation and atrophy; and Yao Gongbo for insanity and the Five Poisons.

Each dispatches plague soldiers, altering their forms with the four seasons. In spring, they follow the clamor of birds to record human curses. In summer, they feign death to visit families, stirring calamity among kin. In autumn, they attach themselves to the Five Earth Lords, becoming hidden dragons in dwellings. In winter, they lurk in the tombs of the Five Clans, intercepting ancestral qi to attack and consume.

The *Zhengyi Zhuan* states: "The various plague bureaus gather the yin ghosts and spirit horses from village shrines, numbering in the tens of thousands, roaming the Nine Provinces, commandeering funeral carts and corpses.
